title: 3.x: Different behavior between blockingForEach and forEach
body:
Hello,

I'm surprise to see that the observable:
```java
Observable.just(0, 1, 2)
    .doOnSubscribe(ignored -> LOG.info("On subscribe"))
    .doOnTerminate(() -> LOG.info("On terminate"))
```

produce the following result with `.forEach(i -> LOG.info("Data: {}", i));`:
```
15:30:25.501 [main] INFO manual.NonBlockingTest - On subscribe
15:30:25.501 [main] INFO manual.NonBlockingTest - Data: 0
15:30:25.501 [main] INFO manual.NonBlockingTest - Data: 1
15:30:25.501 [main] INFO manual.NonBlockingTest - Data: 2
15:30:25.501 [main] INFO manual.NonBlockingTest - On terminate
```

and with `.blockingForEach(i -> LOG.info("Data: {}", i));`:
```
15:32:04.932 [main] INFO manual.BlockingTest - On subscribe
15:32:04.934 [main] INFO manual.BlockingTest - On terminate
15:32:04.935 [main] INFO manual.BlockingTest - Data: 0
15:32:04.936 [main] INFO manual.BlockingTest - Data: 1
15:32:04.936 [main] INFO manual.BlockingTest - Data: 2
```

I expected to have the same result (subscribe, datas, terminate) with `blockingForEach` as with `forEach` without using any scheduler. I have the same result with `subscribe`.

I tested with versions 3.1.3 and 3.1.6.

The documentation does not mention any difference between the two behaviors except that the blocking behavior blocks the current thread (which is what I want).

Did I not understand correctly the difference between the two or it is a bug?

Thanks for your time.
author: JaquierM

comments.body:
Not a bug. `blockingForEach` has an internal blocking buffer that can fill up before the control reaches its consumer callbacks.

In such synchronous cases, the upstream produces all items plus the terminal signal upon subscription, before `blockingForEach` switches to its consumer loop. With asynchronous sources, the production will usually happen on some other thread so the switch to the consumer loop pretty much immediately.

Ok, thanks for the answer.

I was not expecting that difference. I will just move my logic from `doOnTerminate` after the blocking call.

In my use-case, I have several Subjects; some model state (`BehaviourSubject`) and some events (`PublishSubject`). Both, new states and new events, may result from different threads. According to the docs, it is advised to call Subject.toSerialized() then, which returns a `SerializedSubject` (as `Subject`), wrapping the original subject.

This isn't ideal for me out of three reasons:
1) I loose the original subject's signature, for example `BehaviousSubject.getValue()`. 
2) Having only `Subject`s, the distinction between Replaying one, all or none of the previous events, will be clear only from the docs or some other context, but not from the subject's type itself.
3) The need to call toSerialized() isn't obvious; it's in the docs, but it would be better (and more convenient) to have it in the Subject's signature, for example `BehaviourSubject.createSerialized() â†’ BehaviourSubject`. This would make the distinction clear as soon as the IDE of choice provides the auto-completion for available methods.

For the implementation I'd suggest to move away from the `SerializedSubject`, but compose it's synchronization inside the respective original subjects, if created as serialized subject. For the API this would be transparent, as currently only `Subject` is returned and returning the original subject's type from `toSerialized()`would not break this.

author: jiqimaogou

comments.body:
Not in the plans.

Can't you just use concatMap + the current reducer?
is it suitable to call single.blockingget() in reduce?
It can lead to non responsiveness because `blockingGet` is disconnected from the reduce sequence. I don't recommend using it.

> It can lead to non responsiveness because `blockingGet` is disconnected from the reduce sequence. I don't recommend using it.

Can you please help with an example to describe the above bad practice?

I also feel that all Observables should be connected, it's bad practice to use `blockingGet` to convert async to sync. But I don't know why, can you help to explain it?

not only `reduce`, but `scan`, `combinelatest`, `zip`..., why we should not call `blockingGet` in these functions?

Sequences are connected if one sequence knows about the `Disposable` in another sequence(s), or vice versa, hence if one sequence gets disposed, it can notify the other sequence(s).

If you use `blockingGet`, you have to manage cancellations via other operators (`timeout`, `takeUntil`) or make sure the `blockingGet` runs on a scheduler that can be interrupted.
 
Also, most of the time the behavior of the secondary sequence can be joined up with the primary sequence via standard operators (e.g., `flatMap`) or combinations of standard operators.

Blocking can also cause deadlocks or memory leaks in certain `Scheduler`s. Reasoning about blocking is not that easy, reasoning about a mixture of blocking and non-blocking execution requires a lot of experience and thought. So simply avoid blocking with Rx as much as possible.

It breaks operator fusion, which is detected by checking the `Disposable` sent via `onSubscribe`. If, for example, the upstream supports fusion and you relay that `Disposable` to the downstream, it will skip your operator and will talk to the upstream directly.

In general, it is rare not to intercept `dispose()` in an operator.

title: Flowable.fromPublisher work called on wrong thread
body:
Hello! I need to implement some custom behavior in my code. I need to emit new data in my `Flowable` every time when some event occurred. To get this working I wrote the next logic:
```
val signalProcessor = BehaviorProcessor.createDefault(Unit)

fun getData(id: Int): Flowable<Int> {
      return Flowable.fromPuiblisher(signalProcessor).map { 
          Log.d(TAG, "$id Current work thread name: ${Thread.currentThread().name}")
          // Some logic with id parameter here
          id
      }.subscribeOn(Schedulers.io())
}

fun sendSignal() {
    signalProcessor.onNext(Unit)
}

fun testSubscibe() {
    getData(0).subscribe {
        // Some logic with result
        Log.d(TAG, "$it Result received")
    }
    getData(1).subscribe {
        // Some logic with result
        Log.d(TAG, "$it Result received")
    }
    val thread1 = Thread {
        Log.d(TAG, "Signal from Thread1")
        sendSignal()
    }.apply {
        name = "Thread1"
    }
    val thread2 = Thread {
        Log.d(TAG, "Signal from Thread2")
        sendSignal()
    }.apply {
        name = "Thread2"
    }

    Thread.sleep(100)
    thread1.start()
    Thread.sleep(100)
    thread2.start()
}
```

## Expected result:
```
0 Current work thread name: RxCachedThread-****
0 Result received
1 Current work thread name: RxCachedThread-****
1 Result received
Signal from Thread1
0 Current work thread name: RxCachedThread-****
0 Result received
1 Current work thread name: RxCachedThread-****
1 Result received
Signal from Thread2
0 Current work thread name: RxCachedThread-****
0 Result received
1 Current work thread name: RxCachedThread-****
1 Result received
```
## Real result:
```
0 Current work thread name: RxCachedThread-****
0 Result received
1 Current work thread name: RxCachedThread-****
1 Result received
Signal from Thread1
0 Current work thread name: Thread1
0 Result received
1 Current work thread name: Thread1
1 Result received
Signal from Thread2
0 Current work thread name: Thread2
0 Result received
1 Current work thread name: Thread2
1 Result received
```

When `subscribe` method called the worker thread started from `Schedulers.io()` as expected. But when `sendSignal` called all work in `map` always runs on a thread from which `sendSignal` was called and `subscribeOn` is ignored.

## Environment
**RxJava version**: 3.0.11
author: personshelldon

comments.body:
`subscribeOn` affects where the subscription side-effect happen and not generally where the emission happens, especially with subjects and processors. You have to use `observeOn`.

In your case, `subscribeOn`'s side-effect is to emit the initial value of the `BehaviorProcessor` on the IO thread. Since `subscribeOn` does not affect `onNext` calls and `BehaviorProcessor` emits on whatever thread calls `onNext`, you see the non-io threads in the log.

Two more notes:
- `BehaviorProcessor` is already a `Flowable` thus `Flowable.fromPublisher` has no effect.
- You should not call `onNext` from multiple threads without proper serialization; use `toSerialized()` on the processor ensure this.

title: [question] Multiple doFinally and their order
body:
Hi all,

Consider the following:
```
Observable.just(1,  2, 3)
	    	.map(s -> {
	    		if (s == 2) {
	    			throw new RuntimeException();
	    		}
	    		return s;
	    	})
    		.doFinally(() -> System.out.println("error 1"))
    		.doFinally(() -> System.out.println("error 2"))
    		.blockingSubscribe();
```

This prints:
```
error 2
error 1
```

If I move the `map` operator after the two `doFinally`, it prints:
```
error 1
error 2
```

I would expect that, no matter where the `map` operator is placed, I should have always get the second printout of errorX (error1 and error2 in that order). Can somebody explain this behavior?

I 'm using RxJava 2.2.16
author: dmandalidis

comments.body:
When `map` is after `finally`, the crash will first cancel the upstream, and on the return angle, it invokes the finally actions top-down:

```
map.crash
    map.cancel
        doFinally.cancel // 2nd
            doFinally.cancel // 1st
                just.cancel
            doFinally.action -> print error 1
        doFinally.action -> print error 2
    map.onError
        observer.onError
```

When the `map` is before the finally's, the error is propagated to the end observer and the finally actions are invoked bottom-up.

```
map.crash
    map.cancel
        just.cancel
    map.onError
        doFinally.onError // 1st
            doFinally.onError // 2nd
                observer.onError
            doFinally.action -> print error 2
        doFinally.action -> print error 1
```

comments.body:
Test case 1 does not subscribe to the first window in time thus the window gets abandoned and completed. This is the expected behavior.

Test case 2 disposes the sequence and thus the abandoned windows will have no opportunity to emit their only item.

@akarnokd There is a notice in the JavaDocs:

> Note that ignoring windows or subscribing later (i.e., on another thread) will result in
> so-called window abandonment where a window may not contain any elements. In this case, subsequent
> elements will be dropped until the condition for the next window boundary is satisfied. The behavior is
> a trade-off for ensuring upstream cancellation can happen under some race conditions.

Could you kindly describe in more detail what kind of race conditions? From my point of view we can consider windows "active" once emitted, and care only about disposal of windows. And since they are `UnicastSubject`s, there can be only one subscription and only one disposal per window. E.g. if downstream is disposed but there is an "active" window, then upstream stays subscribed, unless the last window is (possibly subscribed) and disposed.

I would appreciate your comments here.

> there can be only one subscription

Up to one subscription. If such subscription ever happens then the upstream may never know it has to stop sending events. The race can happen in some operators, such as `flatMap` for example, which hard-cuts its `onNext` processing upon an asynchronous cancellation, thus the emitted inner window may never see an observer/subscriber.
Thanks for such a good explanation, now it's clear.

title: 3.x: UndeliverableException when using mergeArray
body:
I came across an issue in neXenio/RxAndroidBleServer#4 and I think it's a bug in RxJava and not an issue with how I use it. Please consider the following example:

```java
@Test
public void test() throws Exception {
    doMultipleFailingTasks()
            .test()
            .await(1, TimeUnit.SECONDS);
}

private Completable doMultipleFailingTasks() {
    return Completable.mergeArray(doFailingTask("A"), doFailingTask("B"))
            .doOnSubscribe(disposable -> System.out.println("Starting multiple tasks"))
            .doOnError(throwable -> System.out.println("Error: " + throwable))
            .doFinally(() -> System.out.println("Stopped multiple tasks"));
}

private Completable doFailingTask(String name) {
    return Completable.error(IllegalStateException::new)
            .subscribeOn(Schedulers.io())
            .doOnSubscribe(disposable -> System.out.println("Starting task " + name))
            .doFinally(() -> System.out.println("Stopped task " + name));
}
```

This would result in an unhandled `IllegalStateException` with the following output:

```
Starting multiple tasks
Starting task A
Starting task B
Error: java.lang.IllegalStateException
Stopped task A
Stopped multiple tasks
Stopped task B
java.lang.IllegalStateException  <-- unhandled
```

The same code however works as expected when removing the `.subscribeOn(Schedulers.io())` line from `doFailingTask` with the following output:

```
Starting multiple tasks
Starting task A
Stopped task A
Error: java.lang.IllegalStateException
Stopped multiple tasks
```

The problem seems to be a race condition when two or more errors are emitted at the same time in different threads. I do know about `Completable.mergeArrayDelayError`, however that does not work for my use case as the merged completables are ongoing tasks that never complete (if no error occurs).
author: Steppschuh

comments.body:
This is not a bug in RxJava. When sources race with errors, `mergeArray` probabilistically picks one of them to emit and the other goes to the global error handler.

You have to decide what to do with the excess error that can't be delivered, for example:
- install a global error handler and log/suppress it,
- add an error handler operator to the `doFailingTask` that turns the error into a value or completion,
- create an union of (value, error) as the flow type and work with those.

title: Single and Callable
body:
I was trying to figure out why a benchmark I was running had `Observable`'s `flatMap` to an `Observable.just` with one element running faster than `flatMapSingle` to a `Single.just`, and concluded after adding some `hide`s that it's because of `Callable` optimizations. `MaybeJust`, `MaybeEmpty`, `MaybeFromAction`, and `MaybeFromCallable` all implement `Callable`, as do the equivalents for `Observable` and `Flowable`. Why don't the equivalent `Single` operators also implement `Callable` so that operators like `ObservableFlatMapSingle` can have similar optimizations to `ObservableFlatMap`?

(I've been looking at the 2.x library, 3.x has the same structure, but using `Supplier` instead of `Callable`.)
author: derektom14

comments.body: It was very common to use flatMap with just before, therefore, it received the optimizations. With such shortcuts, one has to beware not to worsen the more common non-shortcut path.
Alright, but why is `Single` left out of these optimizations? Was it observed that `Single.just` was used in `flatMapSingle` significantly more rarely?

This also leads to the strange scenario where, if one writes a `flatMapSingle` that has a very common `Single.just` path, it can be faster if rewritten as `flatMapMaybe`, despite the lack of an absent case.
What is your use case that involves `flatMapSingle` with `Single.just`?

I don't have a specific one right now (just found this quirk while comparing `firstElement()` versus `take(1)`, but the scenario would be something where a key may be mapped to either a value that is already locally available (hence using `Single.just`) or a value that must be calculated by a separate process (hence using a different `Single`). Otherwise, it would be simpler as `map`.

`flatMapMaybe` was optimized because there were use cases that mixed scalar and async inner sources or used just/empty to perform mapping and filtering at the same time. Therefore, it was worth introducing the shortcuts. With `flatMapSingle`, mixed use was uncommon enough so no optimization is implemented.

Ah, ok. From my benchmarking, on an `Observable`, using `flatMapMaybe` performs significantly worse than using `filter` followed by `map` (most likely due to the creation of new objects for every value as well as the greater complication of the `ObservableFlatMapMaybe`). I would need to switch to 3.x to see how `flatMapOptional` compares.

With another benchmark, I've determined that on an `Observable`, using `flatMap` to a 0-or-1 `Observable` is significantly faster than using the equivalent `flatMapMaybe`. This is mostly explained by the fact that `ObservableFlatMap` tries the `Callable` optimization while `ObservableFlatMapMaybe` (but it's unclear why it doesn't), but even when I had `hide()` to bypass the `Callable` optimization, it still performs significantly worse, though not as significantly worse. By all appearances, `ObservableFlatMapMaybe` is a simpler operator than `ObservableFlatMap`, so why this performance difference, and why doesn't it apply the same `Callable` optimization? (I'm still looking at 2.x, perhaps this changed in 3.x.)

Not all possible optimizations have been applied to all the operators. If users are experiencing performance problems, their use case and the operators are investigated. Benchmarks showing such intended use help a lot in determining what actions to take.

I'm surprised that `Observable.flatMap(Observable)` received this optimization while `Observable.flatMapMaybe(Maybe)` and `Maybe.flatMap(Maybe)` did not, then, and that it's more frequent for `flatMap` to involve an `Observable.just` or `Observable.empty` than for `flatMapMaybe` to involve `Maybe.just` or `Maybe.empty`, considering that `Observable` is usually used when multiple items are involved, and if it emits multiple items it can never be treated as a `Callable`.

And I'm still surprised that even when I remove optimizations with `hide()`, `flatMap` is still faster than `flatMapMaybe`, I'll need to turn to the debugger to see how it's taking fewer effective steps.

The benchmarks I'm running are just to directly compare `flatMapMaybe` versus `flatMap`, so they aren't directly reflecting intended use, although I do see many uses of `flatMapMaybe` that can only be `Maybe.just` and `Maybe.empty`, despite being an order of magnitude faster as `flatMapOptional`.

author: VladislavSumin

title: Incorrect number of requests
author: brucelwl

comments.body:
Request amounts are not preserved between async stages, such as `observeOn`, because those manage their own buffers and request patterns. A limited workaround is to use `delay` which does not interfere with the request amounts passing through it.

In general backpressure is not for doing request-response type item generation across multiple stages. For that, you have to use an open loop of a subject/processor, send it the request object and build a chain with `flatMap` or `concatMap` doing the response value generation.

title: Observable vs Flowable on Interfaces With Unknown Implementations
body:
We have a base library which provides interfaces for repository / database access and some basic implementations. In the case of getOne, insert, update, and delete, these all make sense as singles / maybes. However in the case of getAll for instance, this could be a ```Single<List<Model>>``` or ```Observable<Model>```. We considered using single, since that's usually how our data is consumed, but these interfaces could hold implementations that support streaming, so using single would essentially prevent those types of implementations from being realized. The consumer can always use the ```toList``` operator if they dont want to consume it like a stream or need all the results for business logic. 

So now where we are stuck is whether or not these interfaces should return Observables or Flowables. From what I understand, the main difference between the two is that Flowables have added overhead which allow a Consumer to control the rate at which a Producer emits items, where as an Observable does not and will just emit as quickly as possible.

Would it make sense then to always return lower overhead Observables from these interfaces, and to leave it up to the consumer to use ```toFlowable``` if they need control over the rate of the Producer? Would this even work or would the Observable consume memory with its unbounded buffer (potential out of memory issues) before being converted to a Flowable which has bounded buffers?
author: pixelshaded

comments.body: You can always unbound `Flowable` or turn it into a `Single`. Rebounding an `Observable` will be still prone to excessive memory usage. There isn't that much of an overhead difference between `Flowable` and `Observable` otherwise.
It seems then, based on docs, that Flowable is essentially what Observable was in rxjava1, and now Observables are just an alternative to something like Java8 streams. Is that accurate?

> Flowable is essentially what Observable was in rxjava1

Yes.

> Observables are just an alternative to something like Java8 streams

No, they are for cases where there can't be a reasonable backpressure (UI events) or backpressure doesn't matter due to short sequences.
Thanks for the quick replies.

title: Observers run order issue while using observeOn() `2.x`
author: pkrysztofiak

comments.body:
`Schedulers.single` uses a single thread and both of your subjects post work to this one thread. `observeOn` keeps working as long as it sees events so if you post events fast enough, the first subscription will get as much work done as it can, hence you don't see perfect interleaving of the two consumers.

You can try `delay(0, TimeUnit.SECONDS, Schedulers.single())` instead which posts events one by one.

No. Any operator with a queue does as much work as it can in one run, including `observeOn`. Delay has to post events individually as it has to apply an user-defined delay to each, and there is no queue involved in RxJava for that. The underlying `ScheduledExecutorService` will interleave tasks in its own queue. Posting items individually to a thread pool is really inefficient as it causes a lot of extra allocation per task. The way RxJava does this is automatically coalescing nearby events and have one task serving them at once.

title: 2.2.10: Flowable do not use correct scheduler once bufferSize is reached
author: gauthierj

comments.body:
This is an allowed behavior. The `generate` responds to requests on whatever thread the request comes from. Initially, the first batch is triggered on the computation thread due to `subscribeOn`. Later on, `observeOn` takes over with requesting from its IO thread and thus generator runs on the IO thread too. 

The main problem in your code is the position of `subscribeOn`. If you put it just after `generate`, the operator will make sure the subscription and subsequent requests happen on the designated thread.
OK, thanks for the quick answer !

title: Flowable publish not working (2.2.10)
author: abersnaze

comments.body:
I don't think there is a bug in the operator but a misunderstanding.

With `return pubTags.concatWith(untags)`, the shared source `pubTags` is fully consumed in its entirety, then `concatWith` switches to `untags` which now tries to work with a completed `pubTags`.

With `return untags.concatWith(pubTags)`, the `untags` consumes the shared `pubTags` to completion and `concatWith` switches to a now terminated `pubTags`.

Looks like you wanted to have the original sequence and a processed variants of it, but `concatWith` won't let you do both at the same time. `replay(Function)` would cache all items for whatever the second reprocessing would be.

I thought the point of â€˜publishâ€™ was to allow multiple subscriptions to the same`Flowable`.

> selector - a function that can use the multicasted source sequence as many times as needed, without causing multiple subscriptions to the source sequence. Subscribers to the given source will receive all notifications of the source from the time of the subscription forward.

> Subscribers to the given source will receive all notifications of the source from **the time of the subscription forward.**

This is the key phrase. `concatWith` will trigger a new subscription when the shared source has ended, thus it won't receive anything other than the terminal event. The operator is analogous how `PublishProcessor`/`PublishSubject` multicasts items where late consumers will not see previous items.

You are invoking `onNext` concurrently on an unserialized subject, which leads to undefined behavior. This requirement is stated in the javadocs:

> Calling onNext(Object), onError(Throwable) and onComplete() is required to be serialized (called from the same thread or called non-overlappingly from different threads through external means of serialization). title: Subject not notified when using IO scheduler?
body:
In the following snippet:

```kotlin
val myObs = Observable.just(1)
val mySubject = PublishSubject.create<Int>()

mySubject
    .doOnNext { Log.d("mydebug", "called on next") }
    .subscribeOn(Schedulers.io())
    .doOnError { Log.d("mydebug", "error: $it") }
    .subscribe { Log.d("mydebug", "event: $it") }

myObs.subscribe(mySubject)
```

Expected behavior:
Observer is notified. The logs "called on next" and "event: $it" appear.

Actual behavior:
No logs. The observer seems to not be notified.

Notes:
Apparently the combination of using a subject and the IO scheduler causes this. Either removing`.subscribeOn(Schedulers.io())` or subscribing directly to `myObs` produces the expected behavior.
author: ivnsch

comments.body: `subscribeOn` on a `Subject` has no practical effect. It moves the subscription to another thread and you drive the subject still from the main thread. There is a race and thus the `subscribe { Log.d("mydebug", "event: $it") }` may not happen in time to see the value from `myObs`. Use `ReplaySubject` or `UnicastSubject` to ensure a late subscriber still gets all events.

title: Flowable(or Observable) is blocked when thread pool executor throws RejectedExecutionException
author: mshabunin77

comments.body: It's not possible to handle this case from within RxJava. Operators try to schedule emissions/processing and if it is rejected, we can't do anything about it. Signaling onError may run concurrently with existing emissions running on the scheduler in the chain and thus violate the protocol requirements or thread expectations. Don't shut down an executor before stopping flows that depend on it.

Hm, interesting - I tried this scenario with javarx1 and everything is working - I'm getting onError event that I can handle. 

So what do you mean by 'violating protocol requirements or thread expectation'? 
Do you mean that onError will have to use the same executor(or specified in observeOn method) that also may reject?  
In that case I would rethrow rejection exception from observable rather than blocking it, or at least gave the possibility to configure such behaviour. IMHO from thread expectation perspective it's more fair not to hide rejection exception especially when the result is blocking thread.

Solving this may help in cases like this: imagine we have a service with limited thread pool for handling incoming requests and a simple circuit breaker to call another service. This circuit breaker is implemented by rejecting tasks in separate thread pool when the queue is bigger than some threshold or the waiting time in queue exceeded timeout value. In this situation we quickly run out of threads on our service because of this blocking situation and entire service will be down.
I know that hystrix uses similar approach with javarx1. 

Also RejectedExecutionException is valid exception that may be thrown from executors - this fact makes it dangerous to use(or switch to) different executors while using blocking method. 

At my work many developers use javarx1 (mostly simple cases - Single's returned from feign-hystrix and combined by zip or merge) and I was looking at possibility to upgrade to newer stack like resilience4j and javarx2. 
So dealing with this issue would be really helpful and more details would be really appreciated.

Thank you.
Max.

PS. About executor#shutdown - sorry that I included it in my example, it's irrelevant to this situation and by the way it's doing what is expected - every observable emit single event and then blockingSubscribe waiting for completion. After this executor can be shut down.

> I'm getting onError event that I can handle.
That was an invalid behavior in RxJava 1. RxJava 1 is no longer supported.

> Do you mean that onError will have to use the same executor(or specified in observeOn method) that also may reject?
Among other things, yes.

> In that case I would rethrow rejection exception from observable rather than blocking it,
Doesn't work. The flow execution is generally disconnected from the location you are blocking. Also if it were to throw, you lost the flow entirely so no way to retry.

> This circuit breaker is implemented by rejecting tasks in separate thread pool when the queue is bigger than some threshold or the waiting time in queue exceeded timeout value.
This undermines the fundamental expectation that a scheduler can run tasks when the flow is not disposed. Bounded-queue executors will most likely deadlock the flow anyway. Use backpressure and maxConcurrency settings instead.

> while using blocking method
There is rarely any reason to block.
Again, we can't handle this type of resource exhaustion from within RxJava. Avoid blocking and limit concurrency to a level that your entire application is comfortable with.

This is an issue even for non blocking subscribe. In our application we have seen the subscribe call failing silently making the application to get stuck and onNexct calls failing silently causing data loss issues. At bare minimum we expect the execute() exceptions like RejectedExecutionException to be propagated back to the caller thread so that we can catch the exception and take appropriate action.

```java
Flowable.intervalRange(1,4000,0,1,TimeUnit.NANOSECONDS)
        .onBackpressureBuffer()
        .subscribeOn(Schedulers.newThread())
        .map( value -> Thread.currentThread().getName())
        .distinct()

subscriber.awaitTerminalEvent();

```

author: damianofontana85

comments.body:
This is a legal behavior. Using `subscribeOn` with `intervalRange` has no practical effect as `intervalRange` generates items on the computation scheduler by default and has no subscription side-effect to be moved elsewhere by `subscribeOn`. In addition, you are using `onBackpressureBuffer` which may push through an item from the sender thread (computation) or buffer and get replayed by the requestor thread, which in this case is driven by `subscribeOn` and happens on the new thread worker.

title: [2.x] Flowable.parallel() consumes and produces excessive elements.
body:
Flowable.parallel() produces more elements than requested and consumes even more, even if `prefetch` is set to 1.

Sample:
```java
import io.reactivex.Maybe;
import io.reactivex.schedulers.Schedulers;

import java.util.concurrent.atomic.AtomicInteger;

public class TestPrefetch {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        AtomicInteger i = new AtomicInteger(0);
        Maybe<Integer> maybeSource = Maybe.create(emitter -> emitter.onSuccess(i.incrementAndGet()));
        maybeSource
                .repeat()
                .parallel(30, 1)
                .runOn(Schedulers.io(), 1)
                .map(Object::toString)
                .sequential(1)
                .take(100)
                .blockingSubscribe(System.out::println);
        System.out.println("Consumed: " + i.get());
    }
}
```

Actual output:
```plain
1
2
3
...
104
Consumed: 145
```

Expected output:
```plain
1
2
...
100
Consumed: 100
```

Tested on versions 2.2.5 and 2.2.6.
author: daemas

comments.body:
This behavior is acceptable. There are two effects in play here:

1) The parallelism introduces an asynchrony between the decision to stop the sequence and the requesting for more items. 29 of the 30 rails in the sequence can go ahead more before they get eventually cancelled by the 1 rail servicing `take()`. Try with different parallelism level and see it will produce a bit more.

2) If you index the result values you'll see that you get 100 items, but their order can be arbitrary as it may get values from rails that went above 100 due to reason 1). Try this and you see there are no more than 100 item printouts:

```java
AtomicInteger j = new AtomicInteger(0);
AtomicInteger i = new AtomicInteger(0);
Maybe<Integer> maybeSource = Maybe.create(emitter -> emitter.onSuccess(i.incrementAndGet()));
maybeSource
.repeat()
.parallel(30, 1)
.runOn(Schedulers.io(), 1)
.map(Object::toString)
.sequential(1)
.take(100)
.blockingSubscribe(v -> System.out.println(j.incrementAndGet() + " - " + v));

System.out.println("Consumed: " + i.get());
```

Thank you for your answer @akarnokd.
1. So is there currently no option to fetch from the source the exact amount of items requested by the subscriber and process them in parallel? I tried to do it the "old-fashioned" way with flatMap(), but it also seem to fetch a little bit more than requested.
2. Oh, sure, how could I overlook the fact that the order of items is not guaranteed if they are processed in parallel.

There is no way to use the backpressure across multiple operators and async stages to request from a source. Use a feedback loop with `PublishProcessor` where you trigger requests whenever you call onNext regardless of the backpressure status of other stages.

> There is no way to use the backpressure across multiple operators and async stages to request from a source.

Well, I'm trying to understand why, and I'm failing to. I think of a reactive pull-based pipeline. To simplify, let's imagine there are only a producer and a consumer of the items. The consumer asks for (pulls) exactly one item, processes it, and after that asks for another one. The producer does not emit the next item unless the consumer asks for it. Right? If we introduce an intermediate stage, it becomes a producer for the last stage and a consumer for the first one. So when the last stage requests an item the intermediate stage just passes the request to the first stage, and then receives and processes the item and passes the result to the last stage. Then why in my example the very first producer (`maybeSource`) produces more items then requested by the very last consumer? Who requests them in the chain of operators, and why?

Don't think of it as one entity. A flow is assembled from multiple stages and backpressure is negotiated on a stage boundary where individual stages can decide on the request pattern themselves. Some don't interfere, some batch and some keep prefetching when the downstream's `onNext` returns. This is a non-trivial topic and requires a lot of experience to be able to fully understand the consequences. Many times, 1:1 is not even clear to begin with, i.e., when merging two async sources, requesting 1 should request an item from which source?

> Some don't interfere, some batch and some keep prefetching when the downstream's `onNext` returns.

Well, many operators accept `bufferSize` argument, so I supposed I would be able to control the prefetching and batching behaviour with it's help. Looks like it's not the case.

> This is a non-trivial topic and requires a lot of experience to be able to fully understand the consequences.

Indeed, I am not too experienced with the RX library. I came from Scala's `Future` world, where there are no means of controlling backpressure "out of the box", so I had to control and fine-tune it manually in the places where it was necessary. Hence is my surprise to find I cannot fine-tune it the same way with RX, even if I specify mentioned `bufferSize` parameters.

> Many times, 1:1 is not even clear to begin with, i.e., when merging two async sources, requesting 1 should request an item from which source?

Well, there are several commonly used balancing scenarios. Round-robin is my favorite for it's simplicity and general applicability :) Also users might choose one of pre-defined strategies or implement and provide a custom one.

Anyway, thank you for explaining all these aspects to me. Like I said, I'm new to the RX world, and just getting used to it. So I feel I'm just trying to use my old habits within the new environment, and I have to find another way.

title: IO Thread Purge policy
body:
Hi,

we use RX 1.2.7 and we are trying to debug an issue where we see an abnormally high count of idle RxIoScheduler threads (up to 16k) in some boxes even though traffic type and load to all the boxes are evenly distributed. The variance in those boxes can range from hundreds to the abovementioned 16k.

Is this a normal thing to observe for the CachedThreadScheduler in 1.2.7? We don't use 2.x but is this also a common thing for IOScheduler in 2.x?

We have tried different things to troubleshoot the root cause.

1) Shortening the keep alive time of the ThreadWorkers in CachedThreadScheduler gives us mixed results and we are concerned that too aggressively evicting ThreadWorkers could be counterproductive since starting new ThreadWorkers should be more expensive than reusing existing ones in as much as possible, right? We don't want to solve a performance problem by creating another one. More importantly, since production traffic varies, there's a big question mark on what the optimal keep alive time should be and how could we could be forced to keep adjusting the keep alive time frequently. We had hoped that the IO scheduler thread pool should elastically grow and shrink automatically by itself.

2) Another thought is to upgrade to 2.x where we noticed that the purge thread is turned on by default. 
What is the correct way to purge idle IO scheduler threads in 1.2.7 or 1.x? We are wondering if perhaps some code in our application caused the ThreadWorker lifecycle to not terminate correctly and thus hold on too longer than was necessary but we are not sure what. One potential suspect is the onCompleted call. We noticed that different types of clean up happens in onCompleted in 1.x and onComplete in 2.x.  However, we also noticed that the IO scheduler threads are not ended if onCompleted is not called on the Observer in 1.2.7, but they are ended regardless in 2.x even if onComplete is not called, why is this so? Would it be a safe thing to end a ThreadWorker if onComplete was not called on the Observer.

In a nutshell, what is the right way to keep the number of idle RxIoScheduler threads low in 1.x?

Thanks in advance for any pointers that you can share to help us.
author: pp112018

comments.body:
> Is this a normal thing to observe for the CachedThreadScheduler in 1.2.7

No. You have a scheduler leak somewhere. This could be custom operators, manual `Scheduler.createWorker` usages or never ending sources running on those schedulers.

What are you using the IO threads for?

> purge thread is turned on by default

The purge thread removes timed but cancelled tasks which Java doesn't do by default. It has nothing to do with recycling IO scheduler threads.

> Thanks in advance for any pointers that you can share to help us.

- Use `Schedulers.from` with a dedicated `ThreadPoolExecutor` where you control the maximum number of threads.
- You are running a pretty old version, the latest of 1.x is 1.3.8.
- 1.x is no longer supported and 2.x fixed many internal inconsistencies that could have lead to leaks.

We use the IO threads mainly for making asynchronous service calls between services. Many times, these calls are also wrapped in Hystrix, and we provide this as a platform to hundreds of services in production. We found that many of these services are affected, but each extent varies, the severe case in thousands up to 15k. Inspection of the thread dumps show that the idle IO threads were long-lived but did very, very little CPU work.

Can you help us understand the move from setting the removal on cancel policy in 1.x to a dedicated purge thread in 2.x? What is behind the decision to using a dedicated thread in 2.x? 

I also apologize for not making clear our example. So we also surmised that there was some kind of leakage somewhere and one of the testings that we did was to observe what happens if the onCompleted call was not made in 1.x versus the onComplete call not being made in 2.x because we suspected (rightly or wrongly) that this was missing in some of the application code. Our test code is very simple, we use the Observable create factory method to create an Observable and then two Observers that subscribe to that Observable using the io scheduler. We deliberately leave out onCompleted/onComplete when creating the observable and we let the main thread idle for a few minutes to give the evictor thread more than one chance to run after the IO threads complete their work. What we saw was the IO threads forcibly being removed in 2.x but not in 1.x, that was what we meant by the "purging" in 2.x, that the behavior has changed

Please ignore the last paragraph in the last comment, on diving deep into the code, we see what has happened in that test case, onCompleted was required by the SafeSubscriber in 1.x to unsubscribe which will eventually release the thread back to the queue, since this was missing in the flow created by the test code, those IO threads never get released and evicted; in 2.x, the parent Scheduler parent class wraps the work to be done within a DisposeTask that guarantees that the IO thread gets released back to the queue for eviction. The subscription list approach seems quite complex and the DisposeTask very elegant.

So, closing comments from you David, for the sake of repeating for our benefit, given how complex this one example is, there's no telling what foibles exist in our application code, the upgrade to 2.x would be best thing to do for us, correct?

Also, please don't forget to enlighten us on the design decision to use a dedicated purge thread instead of remove on cancel policy?

In general, without seeing your code, it could be both a programming error on your part or a corner case/quirk of RxJava 1.

> Can you help us understand the move from setting the removal on cancel policy in 1.x to a dedicated purge thread in 2.x? What is behind the decision to using a dedicated thread in 2.x?

It needed reflection as it was a Java 7+ feature. Certain phones mess up reflection for one. The secondary reason is that `purge` is overall more efficient and is available to Java 6+.

You can wrap an `ExecutorService` via `Schedulers.from` that has this policy enabled if you really need it.

> 2.x would be best thing to do for us, correct?

1.x is end of life so there won't be any support, changes, fixes etc. to it. 2.x has architectural, performance and API benefits over 1.x. I recommend upgrading to 2.x; most other libraries have upgraded as well by now so it shouldn't be much of a problem.

We would love to share the code with you if we have even the possibility of narrowing it down to a few suspects, the problem that we face is we use RX so widely in our ecosystem and idle thread behavior is so pervasive that it is hard to pinpoint exactly what might be responsible. Some high traffic services suffer the problem more severely than others so the one thing that we are certain of is that it is load induced. Also, since we use RX at all levels and given how common the problem is, what we can reasonably surmise is that it must be some library code. However, it is hard to ascertain if it is a quirk of RX 1.2.7 at high load, or whether a bug exists in how we use 1.2.7 in either our platform or application code as you say. The only thing that is certain from looking at the 1.2.7 code is for some reason, those large number of idle threads were not released back to the queue, because for if they were, the evictor should have multiple chances to reclaim them given how long-lived the threads were.

This was what prompted us to create the abovementioned test case for we saw that the only way a ThreadWorker would be released back to the queue is if onCompleted was called on the subscriber at which unsubscription would happen; or if onError happened.

Just one minor question that I have, it seems like several layers of subscriptions can be created through the SubscriptionList and CompositeSubscription model even for our simple test case, and the code has to work through a bit of unwinding to do before it is able to get to the subscription to effectively release the worker back to the queue. We also noticed that the work to unsubscribe is submitted as a different task to the same executor that handles the work request for the thread worker unlike the DisposeTask which wraps the work request and dispose task within the same runnable. In the face of high load and multiple context switching, does the possibility of race conditions exist for 1.2.7? We have searched quite thoroughly for why onCompleted would not be called in our code and in the absence of any concrete findings, we are wondering if race conditions under high load might somewhat be responsible.

> We also noticed that the work to unsubscribe is submitted to the same executor that handles the work request for the thread worker.

This may lead to a same-pool deadlock if the scheduler is blocked on non-interruptible code, unsubscription may never run.

> In the face of high load and multiple context switching, does the possibility of race conditions exist?

No.

You could have a wrapper `Scheduler` that tracks the calls to `createWorker` and `Worker.unsubscribe` before delegating, so you could log what created those workers.

Race condition inside the schedulers manifested themselves pretty soon during development of RxJava. If the JVM is not broken, there is no way to have a race condition within the schedulers.

> We are trying to figure out why the problem is exacerbated in the face of high load

You could do a thread dump to see what's going on. If threads are waiting in the `LockSupport.park` pretty close to a `ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor`, you don't end the sequences properly. If they are blocked somewhere in user code or external API call, you have likely non-interruptible task.

You can switch to an `ExecutorService` with a maximum number of threads and use `Schedulers.from`, but note that this will eventually hang if all threads get blocked an never unblock.

title: 2.x: subscribeOn does not work when Emitter's onNext called on another thread.
body:
Let's assume we have following code structure
```
import kotlin.concurrent.thread

val dataLayer = Single.create<Unit>{ emitter ->
    thread(name = "John") {
        emitter.onSuccess(Unit)
    }
}

val domainLayer = dataLayer
    .flatMap {
        someHeavyOperation(it)
    }

val presentationLayer = domainLayer
    .subscribeOn(Schedulers.io())
    .observeOn(AndroidSchedulers.mainThread())
    .subscribe()
```
And the problem is that `someHeavyOperation` is called on the thread called _"John"_ instead of a thread provided by IO scheduler. 
**I expect calling `subscribeOn` would switch back to given thread type even if `SingleOnSubscribe` changes thread underneath.**
If that works as designed is there a possibility to wrap code that is called on other thread that does not affect the rest of created stream? I tried a solution similar to:

```
Single.create<Unit>{ emitter ->
    val countDownLatch = CountDownLatch(1)
    var result : Unit? = null
    thread(name = "John") {
        result = Unit
        countDownLatch.countDown()
    }
    countDownLatch.await()
    emitter.onSuccess(Unit)
}
``` 
but it gets complicated when using `emitter.setCancellable{ }` and I wasn't able to think of similar solution for `Observable` type.

I've seen comments in #941, but I can't to write any thread managing code outside `presentation` layer
author: mateuszkwiecinski

comments.body:
Please, next time ask such questions on StackOverflow.

`subscribeOn` is for moving the subscription side effect to some other thread. Your subscription side-effect in `create` is to start another thread which will then drive the downstream, thus `someHeavyOperation`. `observeOn` should be used to move the success value back to a desired thread, which then will trigger `flatMap`:

```kotlin
import kotlin.concurrent.thread

val dataLayer = Single.create<Unit>{ emitter ->
    thread(name = "John") {
        emitter.onSuccess(Unit)
    }
}

val domainLayer = dataLayer
    .observeOn(Schedulers.io())
    .flatMap {
        someHeavyOperation(it)
    }

val presentationLayer = domainLayer
    .observeOn(AndroidSchedulers.mainThread())
    .subscribe()
```

title: 2.0: Operator for specifying used scheduler for all operators downstream
body:
**Question/Enhancement**

Why there is no operator that would enable specifying scheduler used by all operators downstream?
With assumption that `scheduleOn` and `observeOn` would still keep working as they were so far.
 
**Problem/Background**
Recently I learned that there isn't really a concise, reliable way to specify on which scheduler actions from operators like eg. `doOnDispose` or `doOnSubscribe` will be executed. 
Furthermore, position of these operators in chain influences scheduler used by them, which seems logical, but how it's determined is rather unclear - at least from perspective of API. 

Esentially I would like to be able to write code like:
```
repository.getProducts()
    ...
    .subscribeOn(schedulers.io)
    ...
    .observeOn(schedulers.main)
    ...
    .doOnSubscribe {
        products.value = Resource.loading(emptyList())
    }.subscribe({
        products.value = Resource.success(it)
    }, {
        products.value = Resource.error(it.message)
    })
```
and feel safe that `doOnSubscribe` will be executed on main thread.
author: PawlikMichal25

comments.body:
> Why there is no operator that would enable specifying scheduler used by all operators downstream?

Because it is not possible. Operators can't have such reach.

> which scheduler actions from operators like eg. doOnDispose

`unsubscribeOn` affects where the `dispose()` call of its upstream will be called.

> doOnSubscribe

There is no direct support for moving `doOnSubscribe` onto another thread but you can side-effect a different a preceding sequence.

```java
source
.startWith(
    Completable.fromAction(() -> { /* your onSubscribe */ })
    .subscribeOn(mainThread())
    .toObservable()
)
.subscribe(/* ... */);
```

With Kotlin, you can even create an extension method for the `startWith` part.

Thanks for clarifying, just one more question then:

> Because it is not possible. Operators can't have such reach.

so the fact that sometimes eg. action from `doOnSubscribe` is executed on different schedulers  should be considered as a "side effect"?
The `doOnXXX` operators allow you to insert side effect at various points into a flow. They are not predicated on schedulers.

Ok, thanks for responding, 
I will close the issue now

body:
I have some questions about the groupBy operator and its memory usage.

1. Does Flowable.groupBy begin to emit GroupedFlowables as the groupBy keys are encountered or are they held back until the full set of groupBy keys can be identified?  How much buffering of source emissions does Flowable.groupBy do?  Or is it more like a situation where Flowable.groupBy publishes to the GroupedFlowable for a corresponding groupBy key as it's encountered?
2. If I have a very long source Flowable (millions of emissions) which emits its items in sorted order of the value I want to use as a groupBy key, should I be concerned about memory issues (OutOfMemoryError, etc.) with using Flowable.groupBy()?
author: ghost

comments.body:
> Does Flowable.groupBy begin to emit GroupedFlowables as the groupBy keys are encountered

Yes.

> How much buffering of source emissions does Flowable.groupBy

None.

> Flowable.groupBy publishes to the GroupedFlowable for a corresponding groupBy key as it's encountered?

Yes.

> If I have a very long source Flowable (millions of emissions) which emits its items in sorted order of the value I want to use as a groupBy key, should I be concerned about memory issues (OutOfMemoryError, etc.) with using Flowable.groupBy()?

Yes, groups live until they are individually no longer observed or when the source terminates.

Thanks so much for the response, I really appreciate it.  I have some follow up questions if you'd be so kind, then I will close the issue.
> Yes, groups live until they are individually no longer observed or when the source terminates.

When does a GroupedFlowable signal completion?  Only when the source terminates?  In the scenario I described where the source emissions come in the order of the groupBy key, what would happen if I applied a .take(n) operator to inner GroupedFlowables specifying an upper bound?  Would the GroupedFlowables be disposed in that case and then recreated if/when the groupBy key is seen again, or are they still kept alive?

Thanks again

> When does a GroupedFlowable signal completion? Only when the source terminates?

Yes.

> what would happen if I applied a .take(n) operator to inner GroupedFlowables specifying an upper bound?

Assuming you have strictly ordered keys, a take would end a group, freeing the associated resources and the operator would not create another one.

> Would the GroupedFlowables be disposed in that case and then recreated if/when the groupBy key is seen again

Yes.
Perfect, thank you.

title: SchedulerPoolFactory.java null pointer
body:
Location: RxJava/src/main/java/io/reactivex/internal/schedulers/SchedulerPoolFactory.java
Class: SchedulerPoolFactory.java
Line: 69
Statement: if (PURGE_THREAD.compareAndSet(curr, next)) 
Problem: Above this line, it checks if curr is NOT null, and if it is not null, it returns. If it does equal null, it will continue to this line where it passes curr. This can result in a null pointer exception.
author: Xenios91

comments.body: No. The line tries to set `PURGE_THREAD` to the `next` value atomically if the its current value is still `null`. If successful, the purge task is started and the loop quits. If unsuccessful, the helper pool just created is shut down and the loop repeats. There is no circumstance there could be a `NullPointerException` in this method.

See an example below:
```

        subject
                .doOnSubscribe(s->{}) << not called
```

title: 2.x: Concat operator, Maybes, and threading
body:
Following code sample (Kotlin 1.2.51, RxJava 2.1.16):
```kotlin
val m1 = Maybe.just(1).subscribeOn(Schedulers.io())
val m2 = Maybe.just(1).subscribeOn(Schedulers.io())

val m3 = m1
    .concatWith(m2)
    .firstElement()
    .map { Thread.currentThread().name }

var counter = 0
var counterMain = 0

(0 until 10000)
    .forEach { if (m3.blockingGet() == "main") counterMain++ else counter++ }

println("Result: main $counterMain, other $counter, sum ${counterMain + counter}")
````
leads to the following in-deterministic (main number is different for each run) result:
```Result: main 13, other 9987, sum 10000```

It seems that the result of the `concat` operator sometimes runs on the calling thread, even if the participating Maybes use specific schedulers. I could not reproduce this behavior for Observables or Singles. Is this intended behavior and the resulting thread cannot be guaranteed or could it be a bug?
author: schmist

comments.body: This is a peculiarity of the backpressure inside the `concatArray` operator `concatWith` builds upon. If the first source is fast, the drain loop running on the main thread may get the success value and push it to downstream still on the main thread. You have to use `observeOn` before `map` to make sure the right thread is used or apply `subscribeOn` just after `concatWith` so that the drain loop is no longer invoked on the main thread if the above race condition happens.

Thanks for the quick answer!

Since I cannot reproduce it for `Single` and `Observable`, and there are different `concatArray` implementations for `Flowable` and `Completable`, is the assumption correct that this peculiar behavior only exists for `Maybe` sources?
Is this due to the nature of `Maybe` and cannot be changed or could it be fixed somehow so that all observable sources act the same?

This is a `Maybe` specific property as it has a dedicated implementation. `Single` is converted to `Flowable` and `Flowable.concat` is used where the code path is longer for the emission. Try with `Schedulers.single()` for those other implementations so that the scheduling window is minimal.

To be clear, concatenating `Observable`s doesn't have this effect because there is no backpressure to coordinate the emissions with. Each source emits from its thread which passes through the `concat` operator. With `Flowable`, emissions may be held off or simply cached until the value can be retrieved, but this can happen on any participating threads. That's why to ensure proper reception of items, one should use `observeOn` before such `map`s to make sure no matter where the value originated, it continues on the desired thread (until the next async boundary).
Ok, many thanks for your answers!

The outcome is completely within allowed behavior for two things:

- `flatMap` doesn't guarantee that a source thread will be able to push through. It is completely possible that one or few threads will perform the merge for the other threads, therefore, it may appear only one or two threads are only involved pushing data further to the downstream.
- You are measuring the thread use at the end consumer, which is always serialized thus there is no guarantee you'll see that many thread hopping there. Here's a simplified test:

```kotlin
val bigRange = Observable.range(0, 1_000_000_000)
val shortRange = Observable.range(0, 100)

val ts = Observable.zip(shortRange, bigRange, BiFunction<Int, Int, Int> { _, b -> b }).test()
```

`Observable` doesn't have backpressure and `range` is synchronous and will fill up the internal queue of `zip` before giving the chance to the other source. Try with `Flowable` and you should see both cases complete within reasonable time.

RxJava is synchronous by default and you have to introduce asynchrony explicitly.

title: 2.x: Surprising `startWith` scheduling behaviour
body:
Android and RxJava 2.1.8:

I ran into a surprising behaviour of `startWith` that I'd like to verify. I've boiled it down to a simple example:
```
Observable.just(Unit)
                .observeOn(Schedulers.io())
                .startWith(Unit)
                .switchMap {
                    Observable.create<Unit> { emitter ->
                        Thread.sleep(5000)
                        emitter.onNext(Unit)
                        emitter.onComplete()
                    }
                }
                .observeOn(AndroidSchedulers.mainThread())
                .subscribe()
```

In the above example, execution of the observable inside `switchMap` happens on the main scheduler and blocks my UI. 

I would expect that it will happen on the `io` scheduler and it does indeed, as soon as I remove `startWith`. 

I realise I can just add another `observeOn` after `startWith` but it's puzzling. We're already on the `io` scheduler when the `startWith` gets hit, so why would it switch threads?
author: Rosomack

comments.body:
`startWith` subscribes to its argument (constants are turned into Observable.just()) on the current thread and `observeOn` is above it, thus can't have any effect of it. Let me rewrite your code to make it more apparent:

```java
Observable.concat(
    Observable.just(Unit),
    Observable.just(Unit).observeOn(Schedulers.io())
)
.switchMap {
       Observable.create<Unit> { emitter ->
                Thread.sleep(5000)
                emitter.onNext(Unit)
                emitter.onComplete()
       }
 }
 .observeOn(AndroidSchedulers.mainThread())
 .subscribe()
```

As the subscription travels up, the thread hasn't changed so the first `just` will emit `Unit` on the caller thread which then goes into the blocking `switchMap`. 

You can apply `subscribeOn` instead and the `switchMap` will trigger on the background thread:

```java
Observable.just(Unit)
                .startWith(Unit)
                .switchMap {
                    Observable.create<Unit> { emitter ->
                        Thread.sleep(5000)
                        emitter.onNext(Unit)
                        emitter.onComplete()
                    }
                }
                .subscribeOn(Schedulers.io())
                .observeOn(AndroidSchedulers.mainThread())
                .subscribe()
```

or move the `observeOn` below the `startWith`:

```java
Observable.just(Unit)
                .startWith(Unit)
                .observeOn(Schedulers.io())
                .switchMap {
                    Observable.create<Unit> { emitter ->
                        Thread.sleep(5000)
                        emitter.onNext(Unit)
                        emitter.onComplete()
                    }
                }
                .observeOn(AndroidSchedulers.mainThread())
                .subscribe()
```

Ordinarily I would use `subscribeOn`, but sadly I'm using RxBinding which requires the subscription to happen on the main thread.

Thanks for your complete explanation! It makes sense.

title: autoconnect() never reconnects to a completed source
body:
**RxJava 1.3.3**

I'm not sure if what I've found is a bug, edge case or works as designed... Let's roll.

## Assumptions
- Observable, which had completed can be subscribed again and act like it was fresh (at least most of them can (just, custom observables, etc)
- I use the same instance of the observable

## Source observable
Emitts `1` and never completes.

```
val source = Observable.just(1).mergeWith(Observable.never())
```

## Working example

1. Subscribe to source as soon as we have at least one subscriber
1. Source is completed as soon as releaseTrigger emits a value
1. Next subscription (`thirdSubscriber`) to the same observable (regardless it already completed once) received `42`

```
val releaseTrigger = PublishSubject.create<Boolean>()
        val source = Observable.just(42).mergeWith(Observable.never())
        val observable = source
                .takeUntil(releaseTrigger)
                .publish()
                .refCount()

        val subscriber = observable.test()
        subscriber.assertValue(42)

        val secondSubscriber = observable.test()
        secondSubscriber.assertNoValues()
        secondSubscriber.assertNoTerminalEvent()

        releaseTrigger.onNext(true)

        val thirdSubscriber = observable.test()
        thirdSubscriber.assertValue(42)
```

## Not working example

1. Subscribe to source as soon as we have at least one subscriber (due to `autoConnect(1)`)
1. Source is completed as soon as releaseTrigger emits a value
1. Next subscription (`thirdSubscriber`) to the same observable (regardless it already completed once) never receives any value, `autoConnect` won't establish the connection.

```
val releaseTrigger = PublishSubject.create<Boolean>()
        val source = Observable.just(42).mergeWith(Observable.never())
        val observable = source
                .takeUntil(releaseTrigger)
                .publish()
                .autoconnect()

        val subscriber = observable.test()
        subscriber.assertValue(42)

        val secondSubscriber = observable.test()
        secondSubscriber.assertNoValues()
        secondSubscriber.assertNoTerminalEvent()

        releaseTrigger.onNext(true)

        val thirdSubscriber = observable.test()
        thirdSubscriber.assertValue(42)
```

## Analysis

This is due to `autoConnect`'s implementation. `OnSubscribeAutoConnect` maintains `numberOfSubscribers` value, which is never decremented when subscribers are released therefore block

```
if (this.incrementAndGet() == numberOfSubscribers) {
    source.connect(connection);
}
```
is never executed.

## Questions and ideas

- Condiction could be changed to `this.incrementAndGet() >= numberOfSubscribers`. It seems to be pretty safe to call `connect()` on a `ConnectableObservable` which is already connected.
- The counter could be decremented when child subscriber is disposed.
- Some other?
- No, go away, this is intended (please tell me why)

comments.body: The behavior is by design. `autoConnect` is for connecting once, `refCount` for connecting on a `0->1` transition.

It looks a little bit inconsistent with how it works. Do you think that it shouldn't be documented?

Side question, is there any way to introduce required behavior (with built-in operators) or should I keep with my own operator?

I don't understand you. If `refCount` does the expected behavior, use `refCount`.

> Do you think that it shouldn't be documented?

PR welcome.

`refCount` does not do the job because it unsubscribes when there are no subscribers left.

My expected result is to:
1. Connect when the first subscriber subscribes
1. Stay subscribed if all subscribers were unsubscribed
1. If the source is completed and some other subscriber is interested reconnect to source.
This behavior is not provided by RxJava. You have to write your own operator for it.

body:
On RxJava version 2.1.6
JRE Oracle 1.8.111
This sample dummy code never completes.

`Flowable.range(1, 132).groupBy(z -> z % 3).subscribe(z -> {}, err -> {}, () -> System.out.println("completed"));`

                .groupBy(z -> z % 3)

author: daniil-dubin

comments.body: You have to consume the `GroupedFlowable` groups in order to have more items delivered due to backpressure coordination by `groupBy`.

Thanks for your quick response.
With addition of consumption of GroupedFlowable this now completes fine:
```java
            Flowable.range(1, 394)
                    .groupBy(z -> z % 3)
                    .flatMap(groups -> groups)
                    .blockingSubscribe();
```
But simply adding useless but quite legitimate `.buffer(2).flatMap(batch -> Flowable.fromIterable(batch))`
still causes hang.
```java
            Flowable.range(1, 394)
                    .groupBy(z -> z % 3)
                    .buffer(2).flatMap(batch -> Flowable.fromIterable(batch))
                    .flatMap(groups -> groups)
                    .blockingSubscribe();
```
That bizarre code while looking useless is a simplified version of one that processes events in batches in real application.
Adding `buffer` after `groupBy` prevents the immediate consumption of the groups by `flatMap`.

So should it be considered like a bug?
For me it's obviously a problem when via quite legitimate usage of API (I believe that in the code above there was nothing prohibited done, correct me if I am wrong) it's possible to break the system under some circumstances. There should be at least some red flags in documentation discouraging misuse. In my particular case everything has been working fine for weeks until the number of emitted buffered events reached some magic value. That's upsetting.
If it's a bug should I dive into the rx-java internals to try to somehow fix it?

> So should it be considered like a bug?

It is a property of how the fan-out logic interacts with backpressure where the number of groups can't be anticipated by the operator. An emission from upstream could go into an existing group or create a new group with that single initial value. Since group creation has to honor backpressure any delay to bringing that group to a consumer may result in the sequence to hang.

> I believe that in the code above there was nothing prohibited done, correct me if I am wrong

Why would you buffer groups in the first place?

> There should be at least some red flags in documentation discouraging misuse.

You can formulate this warning and add them to the `Flowable.groupBy` overloads' JavaDoc via PR if you want.

> If it's a bug should I dive into the rx-java internals to try to somehow fix it?

This property of `groupBy` has been there for a long time now and nobody so far could come up with a reasonable solution that also doesn't break the Reactive-Streams spec. You can have a stab at it if you want though.

One option would be to have `groupBy` use the on-backpressure-error policy which then will prompt the developer about the need to consume groups. However, this is a drastic behavior change and as such can only happen in a subsequent major release such as 3.x.

title: Use take() concat() skip() together would cause item lost.
author: jie-meng

comments.body:
That is the expected behavior. This is what happens:

1. the range 1..5 is shared through a function
2. the `integerObservable` you get will emit 1, 2
3. the `take` unsubscribes after this two items
4. `concatWith` switches to its second `ObservableSource` and subscribes to it
5. the `skip` subscribes to the shared `integerObservable`
6. the `integerObservable` resumes with 3, 4, 5
7. `skip` ignores 3, 4; relays 5
8. the sequence completes.

So due to `concatWith`, the second parameter sequence doesn't get to interact with the shared sequence until the first half completed.

```java
   .blockingSubscribe(v -> LOGGER.info("received: " + v), LOGGER::error, () -> LOGGER.info("completed"));
```

author: mvoda

comments.body:
This is a valid outcome. `mergeWith` allows errors to cut ahead. Try `concatWith` instead.

title: ConnectableObservable.connect() causes NetworkOnMainThreadException
body:
## Versions 
RxJava: 2.1.0
RxAndroid: 2.0.1

## Issue
I'm using the following pattern to allow me to share the result of an expensive network call across two observables, which both transform the result in different ways:

```java
ConnectableObservable<Model> connectableObservable = doExpensiveNetworkCall().publish();

// Transform in one way.
connectableObservable
    .filter(...)
    .subscribeOn(mDataManager.getScheduler())
    .observeOn(AndroidSchedulers.mainThread())
    .subscribe(...);

// Transform in another.
connectableObservable
    .filter(....)
    .subscribeOn(mDataManager.getScheduler())
    .observeOn(AndroidSchedulers.mainThread())
    .subscribe(...);

// And connect... Uh oh,  NetworkOnMainThreadException!
connectableObservable.connect();
```

This is a very useful pattern, however, calling `.connect()` causes `NetworkOnMainThreadException` as the expensive network call is then run on the *main thread*, despite all subscribers of the downstream observables being on a separate thread.

Is there an equivalent of `.connectOn()` or another alternative which can be used to also let the ConnectableObservable know that it should be run on a different thread? Alternatively, if there's a better way of achieving the above, any guidance would be much appreciated!
author: DCRichards

comments.body:
`publish` turns the cold source into a hot one, similar to a `PublishSubject`, and `subscribeOn` has no practical effect on hot publish-like sources. In other terms, applying `subscribeOn` after the `ConnectableObservable` has no effect. You have to apply `subscribeOn` before the publishing:

```java
ConnectableObservable<Model> connectableObservable = doExpensiveNetworkCall()
    .subscribeOn(mDataManager.getScheduler())                  // <------------------------------
    .publish();

// Transform in one way.
connectableObservable
    .filter(...)
    .observeOn(AndroidSchedulers.mainThread())
    .subscribe(...);
```

title: Task order for Observable.combineLatest and Schedulers.computation()
author: dya-victor

comments.body:
The `computation` scheduler has a number of worker threads that is, by default, is equal to the number of available processors and hands out worker threads in a round robin fashion. Since there is a limited number of them and you block one of them in your first run, the subsequent runs will likely get that scheduler and block tasks behind it.

You are practically wasting schedulers as `subscribeOn` in this case has no effect, `interval` already runs on the computation scheduler and `observeOn` moves the events from one computation worker to another without much benefit.

`Executors.newFixedThreadPool(3)` works differently than our schedulers. We have N x `Executors.newSingleThreadedScheduledExecutor()`, each of them handed out to operators on demand. If one gets stuck, everybody who gets that executor is blocked. 

In contrast, `newFixedThreadPool(3)` has 3 workers which pick the next task from a shared queue. If one is blocked, the other 2 will be still able to pick tasks from the queue.
Thank you!

> Executors.newSingleThreadedScheduledExecutor(), each of them handed out to operators on demand. If one gets stuck, everybody who gets that executor is blocked.

That's a strange design decision. If we replace Thread.sleep() with tough computational work (e.g. several nested loops with large amount of iterations) one of "observeOn" operators will be starving because the other one keeps getting tasks from "observeOn" queue effectively blocking other operator who got that executor.

In case of bad timings, backpressure and conditional logic within "CPU bound" work (leading to arbitrary execution time spent in observer) usage of Scheduler.computation() will lead to completely unpredictable results.

Looks like round-robin policy of handing out pooled worker is very sensitive to the rate of events and time computational work takes. Shared queue doesn't have this issue but may be slightly less efficient.

In any case behavior described above seems conterintuitive. I would except scheduler to try to invoke tasks regardless of "slow" tasks performed in one of the workers.

> That's a strange design decision.

It is designed as such by default to avoid thread hopping that hurts performance in the long run. Plus, if you actually don't block but compute something, you are making progress.

> I would except scheduler to try to invoke tasks regardless of "slow" tasks performed in one of the workers.

The default doesn't do that because most operators expect a FIFO execution and reliable delayed scheduling which can be achieved by a single threaded scheduled executor. 

For all other cases, there is the option of `Schedulers.from` which adds the penalty for forcing a FIFO execution internally in case the underlying executor is multi-threaded and has to use helper schedulers to ensure timing stays ordered.
OK, thanks for explanation.

title: retryWhen() method signature for Observable differs from other Rx types
body:
`Flowable`, `Single`, `Maybe` and `Completable` implementations of `retryWhen()` accept a `hander` parameter is typed that is typed `Function<? super Flowable<Throwable>, ? extends Publisher<?>>`.  `Observable.retryWhen()` uses a different type for `handler` which is not compatible with a handler written for the other types.

```
public final Single<T> retryWhen(
    Function<? super Flowable<Throwable>, ? extends Publisher<?>> handler)

public final Completable retryWhen(
    Function<? super Flowable<Throwable>, ? extends Publisher<?>> handler) 

public final Maybe<T> retryWhen(
    final Function<? super Flowable<Throwable>, ? extends Publisher<?>> handler)

public final Flowable<T> retryWhen(
    final Function<? super Flowable<Throwable>, ? extends Publisher<?>> handler)
```
 versus

```
public final Observable<T> retryWhen(
    final Function<? super Observable<Throwable>, ? extends ObservableSource<?>> handler)
```

It seems instead that this should be:

```
public final Observable<T> retryWhen(
    final Function<? super Flowable<Throwable>, ? extends Publisher<?>> handler)
```

title: ParallelFlowable  concatMapDelayError emits items out of order
author: shakil807g

comments.body: If you go parallel, the source is dispatched to parallel, independent rails that can go on their own speed. If joined together with `sequential` the output order is indeterminate.
but then what is difference between using flatmap with ParallelFlowable and using contactMap ( which emit items in order)
`concatMap` keeps a relative order within a rail and `flatMap` doesn't as it by itself can run sources concurrently that can finish at any time.

ok but how can i go parallel and maintain order as well  ?? and does using contactMap without ParallelFlowable  will work in case of  1000 of message coming in from upper stream and i want to maintain order as well ??

Keeping a relative order between the sequential front and sequential back is not supported by RxJava's implementation. You have to manually pack the data and a monotonic index into a tuple, parallelize the flow and then use `sorted(Comparator)` to collect them back in order. However, when using `concatMap`, you have to unpack the data and then repack it with the original index. 

Without parallel, `concatMap`'s output will remain ordered, i.e., if given an input output mapping of  `a -> (1, 2)` and `b -> (3, 4)`, the operator's final output will be `1, 2, 3, 4` because `a` is processed fully before `b`.
ok thanks without parallel and having 1000 of events coming from upper stream will concatMap flood the system with threads
`concatMap` runs one source at a time and if you use `Schedulers.io()`, the number of threads created will be small.

```
A: ----o----o--|
B:             --z--|
=====================
R: --------------M--|
```

```
A:  --z--|
B:       ----o----o--|
======================
R: ----------M----M--|
```
